Courtland Milloy is a columnist for The Washington Post.
This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
Perhaps you think you have a way with kids.
Well, Emily Yoffe used to think she did.
So Emily, better known to our regular listeners as The Human Guinea Pig for the online magazine Slate, decided to put her child friendliness to the ultimate test.
She signed on as the entertainment at a three-year-old's birthday party.
And here to recount her harrowing tale is Emily Yoffe herself, battered but not broken.
Hi, Emily.
Hi.
What on Earth made you want to go before that audience?
You know, they're little dopes.
You just fall down and act silly, how hard could it be?
Right, but you actually prepared for this, I understand.
Oh, I did research.
I did research.
I went and saw the performances of two of the best known Washington D.C.
children's entertainers, Broccoli the Clown and the Great Zucchini.
And so I went to see both of them, took copious notes, and decided to steal the most boffo bits and I'd have an act.
And what were you, the Great Cauliflower?
I was the Amazing Macaroni.
And my 10-year-old daughter, who I'd dragged along to see these performances, decided she wanted to participate in this as my assistant, so we were the Amazing Macaroni and Cheese.
Ah.
So you get to the party, you've got your routine.
Having a preschooler myself, I know you can't go wrong with a good fart joke, so, you know, how hard could it be?
Well, I'd talk to these guys, these entertainers and Broccoli told me, you know, get on their level, hit yourself in the bum bum, hit yourself in the face, toilet paper, underwear.
So I had all that stuff.
We opened by saying, hey kids, we forgot our hats, and we took out underwear and put it on our heads, expecting, you know, all we have to do is show the diaper, suck on the pacifier.
Dead silence.
There was the toilet paper roll thing.
Now, Broccoli had done this, this absolutely screams, falling down, kids crying it's so funny.
You call a kid up from the audience, I tried to call the birthday boy, he ran away at that point.
I got his older sister, five-year-old sister, to come up and stand next to me.
You have the kid put her two index fingers out and then you go in your bag, pull out a role of toilet paper and put the role of toilet paper on her fingers.
What could be funnier?
That's hilarious.
Dead silence.
Yeah.
Bafflement, embarrassment, horror.
That's when, you know, I lowered myself to eating the toilet paper.
They don't want to do this.
They're human beings.
They have elderly parents and grandparents, but they weren't given any choice.
So Matheny convinced King County, where Seattle is located, to give EMT's more leeway.
The revised guidelines now say that if a victim suffers from a terminal illness and if his family or caregivers say that he would not want to be resuscitated, the EMT's are allowed to stand back.
King County EMT's are unique in the country in that they can make this decision based purely on a verbal request.
They don't need to see any paperwork or medical bracelets and they don't even need to call in for approval.
Paramedic Sylvia Feder helped Matheny design the new rules.
She acknowledges that some people might worry that a sinister family member could trick an EMT into letting someone die.
But she says EMT's are watching out for that.
The patient has to look the part.
You want to make sure that this isn't, you know, the 22-year-old wife that's saying, oh, yes, you know, he doesn't want to live any longer.
King County says so far no one has complained about CPR being withheld, and the guidelines have never been challenged in court.
Coming back from a call, firefighter Felicia Beluchay(ph) says she appreciates the trust that the county has placed in her and other EMT's.
How wonderful is it for us to be able to come into your house and honor how it is that you want to die.
And I think sometimes they want to be resuscitated.
A lot of times they don't.
So it gives us a lot more latitude to use common sense.
And King County EMT's are using this latitude.
Feder and Matheny have crunched the numbers for the last few years and published their findings in the annals of internal medicine.
According to their study, in cases of cardiac arrest, EMT's operating under the new guidelines are withholding resuscitation twice as often as colleagues working under the old rules.
The article suggests that EMT's want to honor families' wishes, as long as they're given the legal protection of formal guidelines.
It's a point of discussion frequently, to be honest with you, of how to deal with the situation.
And I think this article spurs some additional conversation.
Bill Koenig(ph) is the medical director for the Los Angeles County Medical Services Agency.
He says there's growing interest in giving families more power in end-of-life situations.
And many EMT's already defer to their wishes on an informal basis.
But I think it's going to have to happen more formally because it's going to be more frequent too.
That's because more people want to die at home.
But often, when the time comes, the family still instinctively calls 911.
And it's not easy, you know, for somebody to watch a family member without asking for help when they pass away.
Koenig isn't sure the King County rule is right for every part of the country.
But he says no matter what, EMT's have to be better prepared for those cases when people call on them for help, but that help means letting someone die.
Martin Kaste, NPR News, Seattle.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Gas prices soared to an all-time high this week.
Regular unleaded costs an average of $3.19 per gallon.

And with the Memorial Day weekend and the summer travel season just around the corner, many people will hit the road for the beach, the mountains for that family vacation to Niagara Falls or the West Coast road trip with friends.
Interestingly, an ABC News-Washington Post poll finds that record gas prices have little or no effect on people's driving plans, but they certainly will affect your wallet.
We all know that the type of car you drive can make a difference in gas mileage.
But what about how you drive it?
The car world is abuzz with special tricks and tips on how to save gas.
Today, we're going to try to figure out which of these tricks actually work, and which are nothing more than urban legends.
So what secrets have you heard about better gas mileage, and do they work?
